required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Sensitive Periods in Human Flavor Learning
clinical_study.official_title: Sensitive Periods in Human Flavor Learning

brief_summary.textblock: The goals of the proposed research are to specify the timing and consequences of the sensitive period for flavor learning in infants who are being breastfed or formula fed. The investigators will conduct a randomized within- and between-subject study of women and their infants during a 15-month window.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a randomized clinical trial on both breastfeeding and formula feeding infants to determine the effects of the timing of flavor experiences on subsequent food acceptance in both members of the dyad.

primary_outcome.time_frame: 6- to 10-month-old weaned infants (3 separate test days )
primary_outcome.description: Taste testing conducted on infants to determine acceptance of plain cereal, carrot-flavor cereal (exposed flavor for intervention groups) and broccoli-flavored cereal (novel flavor for all groups) after weaning, which occurred at ~ 8 months of age. Outcomes included intake (in grams).

primary_outcome.measure: Taste Liking Ratings of Vegetable Flavors [Mothers].
primary_outcome.description: Psychophysical testing conducted on mothers to rate their taste of carrot, beet, celery, mixed vegetable (exposed flavors for intervention groups) and apple juices using the hedonic gLMS (hedonic general labelled magnitude scale). Ratings on the scale range from -100 (strongest imaginable dislike) to 0 (neutral) to 100 (strongest imaginable like).

primary_outcome.measure: Vegetable Flavor Acceptance (Infants' Rate of Feeding)
primary_outcome.time_frame: 6- to 10-month-old weaned infants (3 separate test days)
primary_outcome.description: Taste testing conducted on infants to determine acceptance of plain cereal, carrot-flavor cereal (exposed flavor for intervention groups) and broccoli-flavored cereal (novel flavor for all groups) after weaning, which occurred at ~ 8 months of age. Outcomes included intake rate of feeding (grams per minute) .

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 6- to 10-month-old weaned infants (3 separate test days)
secondary_outcome.description: Mothers rated infants' enjoyment of the taste of the cereal (9-point scale); aratings range from 1 (extreme dislike) to 9 (extreme like).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Once a month from ages 0.5 - 4.5 months, 10.5 months
secondary_outcome.description: At each visit, infants were weighed and measured to monitor normal growth. These anthropometric data were converted to weight-for-length z-scores (WLZ) using World Health Organization (WHO) growth standards. The Z-score expresses the anthropometric value as a number of standard deviations or Z-scores below or above the reference mean or median value. Normal range for Z score is -2.0 (minimum) to 2.0 (maximum).

arm_group.description: Mothers will receive the intervention for 1 month beginning when their infant is 0.5 months old. Intervention: Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience
Mothers will receive the intervention for 1 month beginning when their infant is 1.5 months old. Intervention: Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience
Mothers will receive the intervention for 3 months beginning when their infant is 0.5 months old. Intervention: Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience
Mothers will not receive the intervention.

intervention.intervention_name: Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience
intervention.description: Groups differ in the timing and duration of exposure to flavored food experience.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy, term infants and their mothers
- Infants 2 wks (+/- 2 wk of age)
- Mothers and infants exclusively breastfeeding or exclusively feeding a cows-milk based formula
- Mothers must be older than 18 years of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- Infants who were preterm or have medical conditions that interfere with feeding or eating
- Mothers who had gestational diabetes or are diagnosed with a major illness requiring treatment or surgery
- Mothers who will be going back to work full-time before the infant is 4 months old
- Mothers who are allergic to any vegetables
- Subjects will not be excluded because of economic status, gender, race or ethnicity.

reference.citation: Mennella JA, Jagnow CP, Beauchamp GK. Prenatal and postnatal flavor learning by human infants. Pediatrics. 2001 Jun;107(6):E88.
Skinner JD, Carruth BR, Wendy B, Ziegler PJ. Children's food preferences: a longitudinal analysis. J Am Diet Assoc. 2002 Nov;102(11):1638-47.

Mennella JA, Lukasewycz LD, Castor SM, Beauchamp GK. The timing and duration of a sensitive period in human flavor learning: a randomized trial. Am J Clin Nutr. 2011 May;93(5):1019-24. doi: 10.3945/ajcn.110.003541. Epub 2011 Feb 10.
Mennella JA, Pepino MY, Reed DR. Genetic and environmental determinants of bitter perception and sweet preferences. Pediatrics. 2005 Feb;115(2):e216-22.
Forestell CA, Mennella JA. Early determinants of fruit and vegetable acceptance. Pediatrics. 2007 Dec;120(6):1247-54.

Llewellyn CH, van Jaarsveld CH, Johnson L, Carnell S, Wardle J. Development and factor structure of the Baby Eating Behaviour Questionnaire in the Gemini birth cohort. Appetite. 2011 Oct;57(2):388-96. doi: 10.1016/j.appet.2011.05.324. Epub 2011 Jun 6.
Pliner P, Hobden K. Development of a scale to measure the trait of food neophobia in humans. Appetite. 1992 Oct;19(2):105-20.
Gerrish CJ, Mennella JA. Flavor variety enhances food acceptance in formula-fed infants. Am J Clin Nutr. 2001 Jun;73(6):1080-5.

Mennella JA, Nicklaus S, Jagolino AL, Yourshaw LM. Variety is the spice of life: strategies for promoting fruit and vegetable acceptance during infancy. Physiol Behav. 2008 Apr 22;94(1):29-38. doi: 10.1016/j.physbeh.2007.11.014. Epub 2007 Nov 21.

patient_data.ipd_description: There is not a plan to make IPD available

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Pregnant women or newly parturient women who intended to breastfeed their infants exclusively for at least 4 months were recruited from ads in local newspapers, websites, and Philadelphia Women, Infants, and Children (WIC) offices. We enroll mother -infant dyads because both members of the dyads were tested.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: No mother-infant dyads were excluded from the study prior to assignment to groups.

outcome.title: Vegetable Flavor Acceptance [Infants' Intake]
outcome.description: Taste testing conducted on infants to determine acceptance of plain cereal, carrot-flavor cereal (exposed flavor for intervention groups) and broccoli-flavored cereal (novel flavor for all groups) after weaning, which occurred at ~ 8 months of age. Outcomes included intake (in grams).
outcome.time_frame: 6- to 10-month-old weaned infants (3 separate test days )
outcome.population: Some of the infants refused to eat (plain cereal: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; carrot cereal: 1M0.5, N=2; 1M1.5, N=2; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; Broccoli: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=3; 3M0.5 , N=1) and therefore the number participants analyzed differs from number in each group

group.title: 1M0.5
group.description: Mothers will receive the intervention for 1 month beginning when their infant is 0.5 months old. Intervention: Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience: Groups differ in the timing and duration of exposure to flavored food experience.

group.title: 1M1.5
group.description: Mothers will receive the intervention for 1 month beginning when their infant is 1.5 months old. Intervention: Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience: Groups differ in the timing and duration of exposure to flavored food experience.

group.title: 1M2.5
group.description: Mothers will receive the intervention for one month beginning when their infants are 2.5 months of age

group.title: 3M0.5
group.description: Mothers will receive the intervention for 3 months beginning when their infant is 0.5 months old. Intervention: Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience Timing of Diet and Flavor Experience: Groups differ in the timing and duration of exposure to flavored food experience.

group.title: Control
group.description: Mothers will not receive the intervention.

measure.title: Vegetable Flavor Acceptance [Infants' Intake]
measure.description: Taste testing conducted on infants to determine acceptance of plain cereal, carrot-flavor cereal (exposed flavor for intervention groups) and broccoli-flavored cereal (novel flavor for all groups) after weaning, which occurred at ~ 8 months of age. Outcomes included intake (in grams).
measure.population: Some of the infants refused to eat (plain cereal: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; carrot cereal: 1M0.5, N=2; 1M1.5, N=2; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; Broccoli: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=3; 3M0.5 , N=1) and therefore the number participants analyzed differs from number in each group

class.title: Intake of plain cereal in grams
Intake of carrot cereal in grams

analysis.groups_desc: Separate analyses of variance with a priori contrasts specified were conducted: 1) to determine whether the 1-month exposure groups (1M0.5, 1M1.5, and 1M2.5) differed from the no-exposure control group to test the hypothesis that the timing of exposure affected acceptance; and 2) to determine whether 1 month of exposure differed from 3 months (1M0.5, 3M0.5 groups) and whether these groups differed from the no-exposure control group (duration hypothesis).
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Repeated Measures ANOVA were done with type of cereal as within-subjects and experimental group as grouping factors. When significant, planned comparisons were carried out. ANOVAs with a priori contrasts specified determined whether 1-month exposure differed from the no-exposure control (timing hypothesis). ANOVAs with a priori contrasts specified determined whether 1-month differed from 3-months exposure and whether these groups differed from no-exposure control (duration hypothesis).
analysis.p_value_desc: Bonferroni adjustment was made and only planned pairwise comparisons with calculated p values of 0.02 or lower significant.
analysis.method_desc: Bonferroni adjustment was calculated and only planned pair-wise comparisons with calculated p value 0.02 or lower were considered significant.

outcome.title: Taste Liking Ratings of Vegetable Flavors [Mothers].
outcome.description: Psychophysical testing conducted on mothers to rate their taste of carrot, beet, celery, mixed vegetable (exposed flavors for intervention groups) and apple juices using the hedonic gLMS (hedonic general labelled magnitude scale). Ratings on the scale range from -100 (strongest imaginable dislike) to 0 (neutral) to 100 (strongest imaginable like).
outcome.population: Two mothers did not complete the ratings on one test date.

measure.title: Taste Liking Ratings of Vegetable Flavors [Mothers].
measure.description: Psychophysical testing conducted on mothers to rate their taste of carrot, beet, celery, mixed vegetable (exposed flavors for intervention groups) and apple juices using the hedonic gLMS (hedonic general labelled magnitude scale). Ratings on the scale range from -100 (strongest imaginable dislike) to 0 (neutral) to 100 (strongest imaginable like).
measure.population: Two mothers did not complete the ratings on one test date.

analysis.groups_desc: Repeated measures ANOVAs were conducted on maternal gLMS ratings with type of juice and time as the within-subject factors and experimental group as the grouping factor

outcome.title: Vegetable Flavor Acceptance (Infants' Rate of Feeding)
outcome.description: Taste testing conducted on infants to determine acceptance of plain cereal, carrot-flavor cereal (exposed flavor for intervention groups) and broccoli-flavored cereal (novel flavor for all groups) after weaning, which occurred at ~ 8 months of age. Outcomes included intake rate of feeding (grams per minute) .
outcome.time_frame: 6- to 10-month-old weaned infants (3 separate test days)
outcome.population: Some of the infants refused to eat (plain cereal: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; carrot cereal: 1M0.5, N=2; 1M1.5, N=2; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; Broccoli: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=3; 3M0.5 , N=1) and therefore the number participants analyzed differs from number in each group.

measure.title: Vegetable Flavor Acceptance (Infants' Rate of Feeding)
measure.description: Taste testing conducted on infants to determine acceptance of plain cereal, carrot-flavor cereal (exposed flavor for intervention groups) and broccoli-flavored cereal (novel flavor for all groups) after weaning, which occurred at ~ 8 months of age. Outcomes included intake rate of feeding (grams per minute) .
measure.population: Some of the infants refused to eat (plain cereal: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; carrot cereal: 1M0.5, N=2; 1M1.5, N=2; 1M2.5, N=4; 3M0.5, N=1; Broccoli: 1M0.5, N=1; 1M1.5, N=1; 1M2.5, N=3; 3M0.5 , N=1) and therefore the number participants analyzed differs from number in each group.

analysis.groups_desc: Separate analyses of variance with a priori contrasts specified were conducted: 1) to determine whether the 1-month exposure groups (1M0.5, 1M1.5, and 1M2.5) differed from the no-exposure control group to test the hypothesis that the timing of exposure affected acceptance; and 2) to determine whether 1 month of exposure differed from 3 months (1M0.5, 3M0.5 groups) and whether these groups differed from the no-exposure control group (duration hypothesis).
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Repeated Measures ANOVA were done with type of cereal as within-subjects and experimental group as grouping factors. When significant, planned comparisons were carried out. ANOVAs with a priori contrasts specified determined whether 1-month exposure differed from the no-exposure control (timing hypothesis). ANOVAs with a priori contrasts specified determined whether 1-month differed from 3-months exposure and whether these groups differed from no-exposure control (duration hypothesis).
analysis.p_value_desc: Because three comparisons were made for each outcome measure, a Bonferroni adjustment was calculated and only planned comparison with P's<0.02 were considered significant.
analysis.method_desc: a Bonferroni adjustment was calculated and only planned comparison with P's<0.02 were considered significant.

outcome.title: Growth of Infants
outcome.description: At each visit, infants were weighed and measured to monitor normal growth. These anthropometric data were converted to weight-for-length z-scores (WLZ) using World Health Organization (WHO) growth standards. The Z-score expresses the anthropometric value as a number of standard deviations or Z-scores below or above the reference mean or median value. Normal range for Z score is -2.0 (minimum) to 2.0 (maximum).
outcome.time_frame: Once a month from ages 0.5 - 4.5 months, 10.5 months
outcome.population: Number of infants who were weighted and measured to determine Weight for Length Z scores (WLZ) during trial; some dyads did not complete the trial so number of participants analyzed does not always match number enrolled.

measure.title: Growth of Infants
measure.description: At each visit, infants were weighed and measured to monitor normal growth. These anthropometric data were converted to weight-for-length z-scores (WLZ) using World Health Organization (WHO) growth standards. The Z-score expresses the anthropometric value as a number of standard deviations or Z-scores below or above the reference mean or median value. Normal range for Z score is -2.0 (minimum) to 2.0 (maximum).
measure.population: Number of infants who were weighted and measured to determine Weight for Length Z scores (WLZ) during trial; some dyads did not complete the trial so number of participants analyzed does not always match number enrolled.

analysis.groups_desc: General linear models were conducted on WLZ scores with time as the within-subjects factor and Group as the between-subjects factor to determine there were differences in growth of the infants over time. This was not done to test hypothesis but to monitor growth of infants during course of trial.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.name_or_title: Julia A. Mennella, PhD; Study Principal Investigator
